messages.text:
The only thing sI will say about the debugger <@U68UUUFPS> is that I have no doubt it will be the trickiest thing to get right.  But I have also yet to sucessfuly use the julia debugger a single time.  I don't mean this as a gripe, it is just a reality for me at least.... anything that is small enough to have usable performance when starting the debugger is something so small that I have never needed a debugger for that tiny of a function.  Maybe there is some sequence of tricks and settings and structure that would work for nontrivial scripts, but I have yet to find it.

So while in principle I think invseting a whole bunch in the jupyter debugger integration (either in jupyterlab or in vscode) is great, it may not be any more usable than the current debugger...

elements.text: The only thing sI will say about the debugger

is that I have no doubt it will be the trickiest thing to get right.  But I have also yet to sucessfuly use the julia debugger a single time.  I don't mean this as a gripe, it is just a reality for me at least.... anything that is small enough to have usable performance when starting the debugger is something so small that I have never needed a debugger for that tiny of a function.  Maybe there is some sequence of tricks and settings and structure that would work for nontrivial scripts, but I have yet to find it.

So while in principle I think invseting a whole bunch in the jupyter debugger integration (either in jupyterlab or in vscode) is great, it may not be any more usable than the current debugger...

messages.text: we support these mime types: <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/blob/0b29e900b4fb8a4d93b07d4af8a8fafa7382a587/scripts/packages/VSCodeServer/src/display.jl#L65-L78>

elements.text: we support these mime types:

messages.text:
```const DISPLAYABLE_MIMES = [
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v2+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v5+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.plotly.v1+json",
    "juliavscode/html",
    # "text/html",
    "image/svg+xml",
    "image/png",
    "image/gif"
]```

elements.text:
const DISPLAYABLE_MIMES = [
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v2+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v5+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.plotly.v1+json",
    "juliavscode/html",

]

messages.text:
I can't execute some commands in VSCode using `run` :
```shell> kma
# KMA enables alignment towards databases, using two k-mer mapping steps and one alignment step.
[ ... ]

julia> run(`kma`)
ERROR: IOError: could not spawn `kma`: no such file or directory (ENOENT)```
Versus in a normal terminal
```shell> kma
# KMA enables alignment towards databases, using two k-mer mapping steps and one alignment step.
[ ... ]

julia> run(`kma`)
# KMA enables alignment towards databases, using two k-mer mapping steps and one alignment step.
[ ... ]```

julia> run(`kma`)

messages.text: Super basic question, but I’m not super familiar with vscode or the extension. How do I test a package I’m developing? I found there is a test task in the command palette, but when I run it it says my package’s name couldn’t be resolved.

elements.text: Super basic question, but I’m not super familiar with vscode or the extension. How do I test a package I’m developing? I found there is a test task in the command palette, but when I run it it says my package’s name couldn’t be resolved.

messages.text: Scrolling up, I see there was a similar question yesterday. Oops. My problem is a little weirder / more specific anyway. I’m using nested projects to provide test dependencies, which I think is supposed to be the standard way now? When I run the test command it is seemingly only picking up the Project.toml in my test directory instead of recursing through the root. My “Julia env” in the bottom bar is showing the root, so I’m not sure what is causing this or how to resolve it.

root.text: Super basic question, but I’m not super familiar with vscode or the extension. How do I test a package I’m developing? I found there is a test task in the command palette, but when I run it it says my package’s name couldn’t be resolved.

Scrolling up, I see there was a similar question yesterday. Oops. My problem is a little weirder / more specific anyway. I’m using nested projects to provide test dependencies, which I think is supposed to be the standard way now? When I run the test command it is seemingly only picking up the Project.toml in my test directory instead of recursing through the root. My “Julia env” in the bottom bar is showing the root, so I’m not sure what is causing this or how to resolve it.

messages.text: I have a weird issue where, if I open a Julia REPL from within VSCode, figures are not displayed. They do show up if I just use a regular REPL. I'm using PyPlot to make figures. I tried it with multiple versions of Julia on macOS. I'm running version 1.0.10 of the VSCode Julia extension. In the VSCode settings I have the "Use Plot Pane" setting set to false. Anyone has an idea how I could fix this?

elements.text: I have a weird issue where, if I open a Julia REPL from within VSCode, figures are not displayed. They do show up if I just use a regular REPL. I'm using PyPlot to make figures. I tried it with multiple versions of Julia on macOS. I'm running version 1.0.10 of the VSCode Julia extension. In the VSCode settings I have the "Use Plot Pane" setting set to false. Anyone has an idea how I could fix this?

messages.text: I think that's a bug in the extension. Will take a look

elements.text: I think that's a bug in the extension. Will take a look

messages.text: Will be fixed with <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/pull/1856>. In the meantime you can call `pygui(true)` to force the PyPlot figures to show up.

elements.text: Will be fixed with
. In the meantime you can call
pygui(true)
to force the PyPlot figures to show up.

messages.text: That works indeed :slightly_smiling_face: Much appreciated.

Much appreciated.

messages.text: Hi, I'm trying to find a way to determine whether a users environment supports displaying of `svg` files as images rather than just plain text. A suggestion from helpdesk was to not check whether `svg+xml` is displayable but rather just call `displayable(MIME("image/svg))"`. That sounded good, but calling this in vscode (which does support svg's as actual images) returns false. Is this erroneous or are there any better ways of achieving my goal?

attachments.fallback: [January 21st, 2021 3:02 PM] niklas.korsbo: Hi, is there a simple way to determine whether a user's environment is capable of displaying an `.svg` as an image rather than as plain text? `displayable(MIME("image/svg+xml")` does not work since it returns true even if the image can only be displayed as plain text.
attachments.text: Hi, is there a simple way to determine whether a user's environment is capable of displaying an `.svg` as an image rather than as plain text? `displayable(MIME("image/svg+xml")` does not work since it returns true even if the image can only be displayed as plain text.

[January 27th, 2021 10:53 AM] sfstreicher: My colleague is having problems getting Julia up and running in VS Code on Windows.

We installed Julia 1.6 beta, installed VSCode, opened VSCode and installed Julia language addon, and installed PyCall in die REPL.
attachments.text:
My colleague is having problems getting Julia up and running in VS Code on Windows.

We installed Julia 1.6 beta, installed VSCode, opened VSCode and installed Julia language addon, and installed PyCall in die REPL.

elements.text: Someone was having an issue with the VS Code extension. I happen to have the same problem. Any solutions?

messages.text: ran into a problem with `LoggingExtras.jl` package - seems like it might be a VS Code specific thing though: <https://github.com/oxinabox/LoggingExtras.jl/issues/41>

elements.text: ran into a problem with
LoggingExtras.jl
package - seems like it might be a VS Code specific thing though:

messages.text:
Basically, after setting a logger, the REPL just gets stuck in StackOverflows

```julia> using Logging, LoggingExtras

julia> global_logger(MinLevelLogger(current_logger(), Logging.Debug))
ConsoleLogger(Base.TTY(RawFD(0x00000019) open, 0 bytes waiting), Info, Logging.default_metafmt, true, 0, Dict{Any,Int64}())

julia> @debug
ERROR: StackOverflowError:
Stacktrace:
 [1] global_logger() at ./logging.jl:488
 [2] min_enabled_level(::VSCodeServer.VSCodeLogger) at /home/kevin/.vscode/extensions/julialang.language-julia-1.0.10/scripts/packages/VSCodeServer/src/progress.jl:29
 [3] min_enabled_level(::MinLevelLogger{VSCodeServer.VSCodeLogger,Base.CoreLogging.LogLevel}) at /home/kevin/.julia/packages/LoggingExtras/wv01O/src/minlevelfiltered.jl:26
 [4] #invokelatest#1 at ./essentials.jl:710 [inlined]
 [5] invokelatest at ./essentials.jl:709 [inlined]
 ... (the last 4 lines are repeated 5649 more times)
 [22602] min_enabled_level(::VSCodeServer.VSCodeLogger) at /home/kevin/.vscode/extensions/julialang.language-julia-1.0.10/scripts/packages/VSCodeServer/src/progress.jl:29
 [22603] _invoked_min_enabled_level at ./logging.jl:81 [inlined]
 [22604] Base.CoreLogging.LogState(::VSCodeServer.VSCodeLogger) at ./logging.jl:386
 [22605] with_logger at ./logging.jl:514 [inlined]
 [22606] (::VSCodeServer.var"#42#44"{Module,String,REPL.LineEditREPL,REPL.LineEdit.Prompt})() at /home/kevin/.vscode/extensions/julialang.language-julia-1.0.10/scripts/packages/VSCodeServer/src/repl.jl:83
 [22607] #invokelatest#1 at ./essentials.jl:710 [inlined]
 [22608] invokelatest(::Any) at ./essentials.jl:709
 [22609] macro expansion at /home/kevin/.vscode/extensions/julialang.language-julia-1.0.10/scripts/packages/VSCodeServer/src/eval.jl:27 [inlined]```
Doesn't happen in normal julia REPL or if I launch julia from a VS code terminal, only with the `Julia: start REPL`

VSCodeLogger
always defers to the global logger to figure out what the min log level should be

messages.text: I'm using vscode remote development together with the julia vscode extension and it's working really well! There is one thing that I could not figure out from the docs. What happens in case of disconnect? Say if I launch a time-consuming simulation on the server and my local machine disconnects or powers down, do things keep running on the server (with tmux used under the hood) or would disconnecting my local machine kill the julia process on the server?

elements.text: I'm using vscode remote development together with the julia vscode extension and it's working really well! There is one thing that I could not figure out from the docs. What happens in case of disconnect? Say if I launch a time-consuming simulation on the server and my local machine disconnects or powers down, do things keep running on the server (with tmux used under the hood) or would disconnecting my local machine kill the julia process on the server?

messages.text: It's very likely everything just dies. There's a setting for persistent terminals in VSCode core, but that doesn't seem to work for Julia.

elements.text: It's very likely everything just dies. There's a setting for persistent terminals in VSCode core, but that doesn't seem to work for Julia.

messages.text: But <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/pull/1893> will hopefully be released in the near future :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: But
will hopefully be released in the near future

messages.text: ah, I see, so one could just launch a julia-REPL in a tmux session and connect vscode to that? I guess for the time being I'll just do that manually and use a separate REPL for long computations

elements.text: ah, I see, so one could just launch a julia-REPL in a tmux session and connect vscode to that? I guess for the time being I'll just do that manually and use a separate REPL for long computations

messages.text: it's pretty tricky to get right without code changes in the extension, but you might be able to hack something together

messages.text:
2 questions:
1. What's the VSCode friendly way of setting up BenchmarkTools, Revise and OhMyREPL as a startup image? With the clickbox on settings + PackageCompiler?
2. Does anyone else use a vim movement keys extension? My nvim vscode extension is super janky and sometimes becomes unresponsive and I need to relaod vscode - very aggravating. Has anyone had any success with a particular vim extension or faced this problem before?
Thx!

What's the VSCode friendly way of setting up BenchmarkTools, Revise and OhMyREPL as a startup image? With the clickbox on settings + PackageCompiler?

2. Does anyone else use a vim movement keys extension? My nvim vscode extension is super janky and sometimes becomes unresponsive and I need to relaod vscode - very aggravating. Has anyone had any success with a particular vim extension or faced this problem before?
Thx!

messages.text: This is too anecdotal for me to report, but has anyone else noticed the inline evaluation randomly hanging for like ~30sec every once in a while with some of the recent insiders builds? Like I'll hit Ctrl+Enter and it'll take ~30sec for the little ⟳ to pop up at all, but eventually it does and it finishes without me doing anything. In the past this has been accompanied by the language server crashing as indicated on the Julia Language Server output, but here that seems fine, its not crashing.

elements.text: This is too anecdotal for me to report, but has anyone else noticed the inline evaluation randomly hanging for like ~30sec every once in a while with some of the recent insiders builds? Like I'll hit Ctrl+Enter and it'll take ~30sec for the little ⟳ to pop up at all, but eventually it does and it finishes without me doing anything. In the past this has been accompanied by the language server crashing as indicated on the Julia Language Server output, but here that seems fine, its not crashing.

messages.text: I suspect that something is crashing anyways

elements.text: I suspect that something is crashing anyways
